title: How to get hold of someone who can write book if I have a story to tell - Quora

response.answer_text: Ghostwriting has been a time-honored profession in the publishing industry. There are many people who have interesting stories to tell, but are absolutely terrible at writing or putting those stories in text in a logical manner. Ghostwriting is also very secretive, as most people who have had their books ghostwritten don’t want the public to know they weren’t really the ones who put their words into narrative prose. Also, readers tend to bristle when they discover the person whose name is on the cover wasn’t actually the person who wrote the book. This very negative reaction is the key reason that most publishers try to keep the ghostwriting as secretive as possible. James Patterson has sold over 300 million books. He regularly uses ghostwriters for his novels, admitting that he is much better at dreaming up the plots than he is producing the actual prose. To be fair, Patterson credits his ghostwriters by naming them as cowriters on his novels. So he is very open about the fact that he employs ghostwriters. Most celebrities who have “written” books did not actually write their books. The ghostwriter who is hired to write for them may spend several months interviewing the celebrity on the subjects the celebrity wants to touch upon about their lives and then writes the prose based on those interviews. The work is then reviewed by the celebrity, to make sure there aren’t any irregularities or false entries—or stuff they don’t want public—and the ghostwriter adjusts those parts as requested. When the manuscript is completed, it goes to editing, then publishing. Why use a ghostwriter? In the case of most celebrities, they don’t have the time to write while working at whatever it is that made them famous. Some people have interesting stories to tell, but just cannot write it out. Others have great story ideas, but cannot put those ideas to words. Why would someone want to be a ghostwriter? There are some people who love to write, but lack the talent to create story ideas. I have friends who look at me like I’m some sort of monster because of how all these wild ideas keep coming out of me. A common question I’ve heard all my life is, “How the %#@! do you come up with this stuff?!” Just because someone can’t come up with a story idea doesn’t mean they can’t write beautifully if given an idea to run with.

Often, writing the story yourself is best. You have extensive knowledge of the story. You can put words and emotions into the story that no one else can. The way that you write the story will be significantly different that someone else. But, if you are completely opposed to writing the story, then try to find a family member or friend who is willing. Or possibly someone they know. Don’t limit yourself just because you have not done something before.

It really depends on what you want to do with that story: do you want to share it with family and friends? You can search for a creative writing course and pen it down yourself, maybe with the help of a tutor. If you think the story is really good and should be published, you can write a small pitch and contact literary agents: if they find it compelling they’ll sifr you with a ghost writer :)

Any publishing company, or any writer. For starters, answer all the main questions, who, what ,where , when, why, and how, for all the main characters on a disc or tape recording. If possible, section it off. to it for all the main parts of the story. So the story stays fresh. and then send that in to a publisher or make copies.
You can read some books about it and do some courses. That would be a lot cheaper and your own work.
